sorcer.service
Interface Exertion

All Superinterfaces:
Evaluation<Object>, Identifiable, Invocation<Object>, Serializable, Service
All Known Subinterfaces:
AsyncExertion, MonitoredExertion
All Known Implementing Classes:
IfExertion, Job, NetJob, NetTask, ObjectJob, ObjectTask, ServiceExertion, SignedServiceTask, Task, WhileExertion
public interface Exertion
extends Service, Evaluation<Object>, Invocation<Object>, Serializable, Identifiable

An exertion is a federated service command (statement) communicated by a requestor - Service.service(sorcer.service.Exertion, net.jini.core.transaction.Transaction), to a service provider Service. It is a form of service-oriented message with an enclosed service Context and a collection of service Signatures. The service dataContext specifies service data to be processed by the service providers matching exertion's signatures. An exertion's signature can carry own implementation when its type is associated with a provided codebase.
Exertions are request interseptors in the form of command objects (in the Command programming pattern) that keep a service requestor completely separate from the actions that service providers carry out. Exertions are also completely separate from each other and do not know what other exertions do. However, they can pass parameters via contexts by mapping Context.map(java.lang.String, java.lang.String, sorcer.service.Context) expected input dataContext values in terms of expected output values calculated by other exertion. The operation exert(net.jini.core.transaction.Transaction, sorcer.service.Parameter...) of this interface provides for execution of desired actions enclosed in exertions, thus keeping the knowledge of what to do inside of the exertions, instead of having another parts of SO program to make these decisions. When an exertion is invoked then the exertion redirects control to a dynamically bound Service matching the exertion's signature of type Operate PROCESS.
The Exertion interface also provides for the Composite design pattern and defines a common elementary behavior for all exertions of Task type and control flow exertions (for branching and looping). A composite exertion called Job contains a collection of elementary, flow control, and other composite exertions with the same elementary behavior performed collectively by all its members. Thus Tasks and control flow exertions are analogous to programming statements and Jobs analogous to procedures in conventional procedural programming.
Control flow exertions allow for branching and looping operations by Services executing exertions. A job combined from tasks and other jobs along with relevant control flow exertions is a service-oriented procedure that can federate its execution with multiple service providers bound dynamically in runtime as determined by Signatures of job component exertions.

Author:
Mike Sobolewski
See Also:
AsyncExertion

getSignatures

List<Signature> getSignatures()
Returns a process signature, all pre-processing, post-processing, and append signatures. There is only one process signature defining late binding to the service provider processing this exertion.

Returns:
a collection of all service signatures
See Also:
getProcessSignature()

getProcessSignature

Signature getProcessSignature()
Returns a signature of the PROCESS type for this exertion.

Returns:
a process service signature
See Also:
getSignatures()

getFlowType

Strategy.Flow getFlowType()
Returns a flow type for this exertion execution. A flow type indicates if this exertion can be executed sequentially, in parallel, or concurrently with other component exertions within this exertion. The concurrent execution requires all mapped inputs in the exertion dataContext to be assigned before this exertion can be executed.

Returns:
a flow type
See Also:
Flow}.

getAccessType

Strategy.Access getAccessType()
Returns a provider access type for this exertion execution. An access type indicates whether the receiving provider specified in the exertion's process signature is accessed directly (Acess.PUSH) or indirectly (Acess.PULL) via a shared exertion space.

Returns:
an access type
See Also:
Access}.

exert

<T extends Exertion> T exert(Transaction txn,
                             Parameter... entries)
                         throws TransactionException,
                                ExertionException,
                                RemoteException
Sends this exertion to the assigned service provider if set. If a service provider is not set then in runtime it bounds to any available provider that matches this exersion's signature of the PROCESS type.

Parameters:
txn - The transaction (if any) under which to exert.
Returns:
a resulting exertion
Throws:
TransactionException - if a transaction error occurs
ExertionException - if processing this exertion causes an error
RemoteException

boolean isWaitable()

Returns:
true if this exertion is returned synchronously.

isJob

boolean isJob()
Returns true if this exertion requires execution by a Jobber, otherwise false if this exertion requires its execution by a Tasker. Note that control follow exertion can be processed by either a Tasker or a Jobber.

Returns:
true if this exertion requires execution by a Jobber.

boolean isTree()

true if this exertion is atop an acyclic graph in which no node has two parents (two references to it).
